questions.prompt: The CE amplifier voltage gain A_V equals:
questions.explanation: A_V = -g_m·R_C. The negative sign indicates phase inversion (180°).

questions.prompt: The input impedance of a CE amplifier is:
questions.explanation: R_in = r_π || R₁ || R₂. The bias resistors are in parallel with r_π from the small-signal perspective.
CE inverts: when V_in increases, I_C increases, V_RC increases, so V_CE decreases. Positive input → negative output.

questions.prompt: Adding unbypassed R_E to a CE amplifier will:
questions.explanation: With R_E: A_V = -R_C/(r_e + R_E). Gain drops but linearity and thermal stability improve via negative feedback.

questions.prompt: If I_C = 1 mA at room temperature, g_m equals:
questions.explanation: g_m = I_C/V_T = 1mA/25mV = 40 mA/V. At room temperature V_T ≈ 25 mV.

The output impedance of a CE amplifier (with Early effect neglected) is approximately:
questions.explanation: R_out ≈ R_C when early effect (r_o) is neglected. With r_o: R_out = R_C || r_o.

questions.prompt: Why is the CE configuration the most commonly used BJT amplifier?
questions.explanation: CE has both high voltage gain and high current gain (β), giving the highest power gain A_P = |A_V| × A_I among all three BJT configs.

questions.prompt: The bypass capacitor C_E is used to:
questions.explanation: C_E bypasses R_E for AC, restoring the full gain -g_m·R_C. Without C_E, gain is reduced to -R_C/(r_e+R_E).
